title: Welcome
text:
This is a repository for a bunch of solutions that I have developed to solve specific issues that I am tackling in my work with international large-scale assessment (ILSA) data. If you are here, you probably know that these data have several idiosyncrasies including the sampling and assessment designs, both of which necessitate specialized treatment (i.e., you can’t just plug these data into your favorite analysis tool and produce statistics willy-nilly).
This is a living document that I will try, to the best of my ability and available time, to update with tools (mostly R functions and code) that I find useful.
If you find errors or areas for improvement, I welcome your feedback.

title: About Me
text:
I am a professor of quantitative research methodology at Indiana University. In this position, I conduct methodological research in the enormous playground of international large-scale assessment (ILSA). You can see my Google Scholar page for details on my recent and most cited publications.
I teach courses in social science statistics, including latent variable modeling, multilevel modeling, categorical data analysis, and, occasionally, a course on missing data analysis. I am also very interested in assessment design, especially across countries, and how we can model and compare scores on tests of common domains like math, science, and reading.
In addition to my research and teaching duties, I serve in a number of international and national roles. These include chair of the PISA Technical Advisory Group (since 2020), a member of the IEA’s Technical Executive Group (since 2024), and as chair of the US NAEP Questionnaire Standing Committee (since 2018. Or at least I think I still do. Does it still exist? I actually don’t know. But let’s just say no one fired me from this role. Or at least, they didn’t tell me my services are no longer needed).

title: Right-Side PVs and Benchmarks
text:
Here, I’m sharing an R script that serves as a wrapper for WeMix. The point is to be able to put PVs (and benchmarks) on the right-hand side of the equation, rather than the left-hand side where they normally are as response variables.
This function also conducts analysis by-group (by country in the analysis that I did).
There are use examples at the end.



Wraps around WeMix to fit multilevel models where the PVs and/or benchmarks IVs
Pools results using Rubin’s (1987) rules for multiple imputation




Download the full analysis: fit_wemix_by_group_pv_v11.R

title: lsa simulation example
text:
Here is an R script that shows how I simulated a single-group’s (e.g., country) ILSA responses. I used the R package lsasim. There are 3 correlated domains (i.e., math, reading, science) and several background variables that have different scales (continuous, ordinal, and binary) and that have different correlations with \(\theta\) and with each other.
I also generated items by domain with specified distributions. Then, these items were assembled into blocks, which were assigned to booklets/forms. These simulated forms were then distributed in a random fashion to each simulated examinee. This, generally, follows non-adaptive ILSA administration.I also process the background variables via a principal component analysis, which also generally follows ILSA operational procedures.
I set all of this up in a loop and repeated the process 100 times for stability. You’ll notice that in step 1, where I set up the generating parameters, these values are fixed over replications. But all the draws from these generating parameters are random (but replicable if you use the same seed - see line 86).
Everything is saved in a list in this simulation, including all simulated item parameters and response data per replication along with the generating parameters.
I’ve commented the code so that I think it’s readable. Let me know if you have suggestions for improvements. ## Complete R Script
Download the full script: lsa data generation x 100.R
